alert.note: Alert for Chaves County Plains; Chuska Mountains; Curry County; De Baca County; Eastern Lincoln County; Espanola Valley; Estancia Valley; Far Northwest Highlands; Harding County; Jemez Mountains; Lower Rio Grande Valley; Middle Rio Grande Valley, Albuquerque Metro Area; Northwest Highlands; Northwest Plateau; Roosevelt County; San Agustin Plains and Adjacent Lowlands; San Francisco River Valley; Sandia, Manzano Mountains Including Edgewood; Santa Fe Metro Area; South Central Highlands; South Central Mountains; Southwest Chaves County; Southwest Mountains; Tusas Mountains Including Chama; Union County; Upper Rio Grande Valley; Upper Tularosa Valley; West Central Highlands; West Central Mountains; West Central Plateau (New Mexico) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Albuquerque (Northern and Central New Mexico)
info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued January 05 at 3:52AM MST by NWS Albuquerque
info.description: ...INCREASING POTENTIAL FOR A SIGNIFICANT WINTER STORM AND DANGEROUS WIND CHILLS FOR NORTHERN AND CENTRAL NEW MEXICO. INCREASING CONFIDENCE FOR BLIZZARD CONDITIONS ACROSS NORTHEAST NEW MEXICO... A winter storm will dive down from the Gulf of Alaska and Pacific Northwest this weekend approaching northwest NM Sunday morning. A band of snow is expected on the leading end of the system resulting in hazardous travel and road conditions across northern and western NM during the day Sunday. Snow is expected to enter the Santa Fe and Albuquerque Metros come Sunday evening as the center of the storm approaches the Four Corners. This will result in the potential for hazardous road conditions Sunday night into Monday morning, thus impacting the Monday morning commute. As the core of the storm moves across the state and approaches the Texas border Monday afternoon, a heavy band of snow looks to develop on the backside of the low center across northeast NM. Locally higher snowfall amounts could be possible within this band. In addition to the snow, strong north winds of 30 to 40 mph with gusts of up to 55 mph will be present. These strong winds along with the snow will likely result in blizzard conditions across northeast during the day Monday lingering into Monday night as the storm exits east. Finally, extremely cold temperatures are expected on Monday night in the wake of this winter storm. Temperatures will plummet to the lowest reading of the winter season to date with lows below to near 0 across northern and western NM and single digits to mid teens across the middle to lower Rio Grande Valley and eastern NM. This will result in dangerously cold wind chills ranging from as low as -40 degrees at Angel Fire in the northern mountains to single digits to mid teens across the Rio Grande Valley and eastern plains. Temperatures slowly warm up Tuesday and Wednesday. However, highs will remain around 5 to 13 below normal for most on Wednesday.
